file_name: Pakistan_Monsoon floods and rains in Pakistan-Week 31 2024
summary: Pakistan is currently grappling with widespread monsoon rains and flash floods, which between July 1 and August 1, led to 108 deaths, 216 injuries, and damage to over 550 houses, predominantly affecting Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and Punjab provinces[10]. Urban flooding has been reported in various areas, with Lahore experiencing record rainfall that caused significant disruption, including electricity suspension, road closures, and submerged hospitals[13]. The floods have also damaged critical infrastructure such as bridges and roads, disrupting traffic in KP and Kashmir[10]. The Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) has issued an "ALERT" for more torrential monsoon rains from August 1-6, warning of potential further flash flooding and landslides nationwide[14][17][18]. Simultaneously, the country is experiencing social unrest, including protests near the capital over escalating power bills and demonstrations in Balochistan concerning human rights, where hundreds have been detained and an internet shutdown imposed[25]. Additionally, a violent land dispute in Parachinar, Kurram, has resulted in significant casualties and a temporary ceasefire[15].

10.context: The Pakistan Meteorological Department PMD has predicted more rains from 1-6 August with an advisory to remain on "ALERT" as heavy rainfall may cause further flooding.SITUATIONAL UPDATEAccording to NDMA reports, Heavy rainfall between 1 July  1 August led to flash floods, resulting in 108 deaths 33 men, 20 women, 55 children, 216 injuries 81 men, 55 women, 80 children, and damage to over 550 houses. The floods mainly impacted KP and Punjab provinces, with urban flooding reported in some areas. The flash floods damaged bridges, roads, social infrastructure and disrupted traffic on national highways in KP and Kashmir.Reports from NDMA indicate that rain-related incidents caused 40 deaths 17 men, 8 women, 15 children, 81 injuries 31 men, 22 women, 28 children, damage to 448 houses, 5 Schools, 36 other shelters and the loss of 40 livestock.

25.context: title: Pakistan: Respect Rights in Response to Balochistan March  content: New York  Pakistani authorities should exercise restraint in responding to demonstrations in Balochistan province, release all detained for peaceful protest, and restore internet access, Human Rights Watch said today.Since July 28, 2024, Pakistani authorities have detained hundreds of people in response to the Baloch National Gathering, a march seeking to raise awareness of human rights concerns in Balochistan. Some protesters reportedly attacked security forces, killing one soldier and injuring others. Baloch activists have alleged that government security forces have used excessive force to prevent protesters from reaching the port city of Gwadar, the end point of the march. Government authorities have imposed an internet shutdown on Gwadar.
25.title: Pakistan: Respect Rights in Response to Balochistan March

clusters.cluster_headline: Monsoon Rains Fail to Deter Protests Over Pakistan's Rising Energy Costs
clusters.cluster_summary:
Despite the pouring monsoon rains, approximately 3,000 supporters of a major Islamist party continued a sit-in protest on a main road into Pakistan's capital, demonstrating against skyrocketing power bills[1][41]. These protests persisted even as the monsoon season brought heavy rains, highlighting the public's frustration with energy costs that have more than doubled for some due to added taxes[41]. A private school teacher in Lahore expressed that half of her salary now goes to the energy bill, making it difficult to manage household expenses[41].

In Pakistan's southwest, thousands protested against police violence, an internet shutdown, and highway closures, although these grievances were not directly linked to the monsoon floods or rains[11][35]. The sources do not explicitly connect these protests to the security situation in Balochistan or the activities of insurgent groups[35].

In Gwadar, nearly 100,000 residents depend on natural sources such as rain and traditional dams for water[25][51]. However, the sources do not specify how monsoon floods or rains have exacerbated challenges related to basic necessities for Gwadar residents[51]. While the monsoon rains are mentioned in the context of protests over power bills, there is no direct link to the tensions between the Baloch population and the federal government[27].

1.context: title: Skyrocketing power bills draw protests near Pakistan's capital  content: Skyrocketing power bills draw protests near Pakistan's capitalProtests over skyrocketing power bills shut down a major road into Pakistan's capital on Monday as some 3,000 supporters of a major Islamist party continued a sit-in despite pouring monsoon rains.In Pakistan's southwest, meanwhile, thousands protested against police violence, an internet shutdown and highway closures. Officials say the increases were needed to meet conditions set by the International Monetary Fund for a 7 billion loan deal made earlier this month.The government has also added a confusing bevy of taxes on top of the base price, adding up to a bill that has more than doubled for some Pakistanis. "This month I paid 22,000 rupees 80 for my electricity bill, while in May I only paid 10,000 rupees 36," said Asma Humayon, who teaches at a private school in the city of Lahore. "I don't know how to run the kitchen; now half of my salary is going to energy bill.
1.title: Skyrocketing power bills draw protests near Pakistan's capital

clusters.cluster_headline: Pakistan Faces Dual Crisis: Malnutrition and Severe Monsoon Flooding Challenges
clusters.cluster_summary:
Pakistan is grappling with a complex malnutrition crisis, characterized by high levels of undernutrition, micronutrient deficiencies, and a rising prevalence of overweight and obesity, along with diet-related non-communicable diseases. This situation underscores the urgent need to review and update the National Community-based Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) guidelines to align with the latest national and global recommendations, ensuring the quality and effectiveness of CMAM protocols, strategies, and implementation[1].

Concurrently, Pakistan is facing severe challenges due to monsoon rains, particularly in urban areas like Lahore. The city experienced a record rainfall of 337 millimeters, leading to overwhelmed drainage systems, urban flooding, electricity suspension, road closures, and submerged hospitals and low-lying areas[14][16][18]. In response, efforts are underway to pump rainwater off main roads, with Wasa's drainage operations continuing without interruption[15][16]. City and District Administrations have been instructed to implement contingency plans for flood-vulnerable urban centers, including prompt de-watering operations in flooded areas[20]. Rescuers across the province are actively working to assist those affected[12]. Additionally, the NHA, FWO, and Local CW Departments are tasked with ensuring the pre-placement of machinery and timely restoration of damaged road linkages[12].

The Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) has issued an advisory to relevant authorities, urging them to remain "ALERT" and take necessary measures to prevent any untoward situations[27][30]. The PMD predicts that torrential monsoon rains may generate flash flooding in local nullahs/streams and landslides, potentially causing road closures in vulnerable hilly areas[21][27]. Heavy rainfall is expected to exacerbate flooding conditions[26].

The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) is actively responding to the monsoon rains by reporting on rain-related incidents, including casualties and damages[35]. The NDMA has warned that various parts of the country are likely to experience urban and flash flooding, with current and future rain spells projected[32]. It has issued advisories indicating that monsoon currents are expected to affect central and southern parts of the country, with heavy rainfall anticipated[33]. To mitigate the impact of potential urban flooding, efforts are underway to pump rainwater off main roads[38]. The NDMA advises populations at risk to avoid floodwaters and seek safe locations, and it recommends avoiding crossing bridges if water is flowing rapidly due to their hazardous nature during floods[31][35].

The National Emergencies Operation Centre (NEOC) is addressing the risk of urban flooding by forecasting rainfall and thundershowers in southern and northeastern Punjab and northeastern Sindh, which may trigger urban flooding in these regions[41]. Populations at risk are advised to avoid floodwaters and find safe locations away from flood-prone areas, ensuring roofs and windows are properly sealed to prevent water leakage[41].

The sixth spell of monsoon rains in Punjab, predicted from August 1 to 6, is expected to bring strong winds and thundershowers[51]. Heavy rainfall during this period may cause further flooding[57]. Torrential monsoon rains are anticipated, which may generate flash flooding in local nullahs/streams and cause landslides leading to road closures in vulnerable hilly areas[56]. Intense rain-windstorms and thundershowers with heavy to very heavy rainfall are also expected in Punjab from August 1 to 7, 2024[59]. Most districts of south Punjab are likely to face strong winds and thundershowers, with monsoon rains expected in Rawalpindi, Gujranwala, Sargodha, Multan, Dera Ghazi Khan, Bahawalpur, Lahore, Faisalabad, Sahiwal, and Gujarat divisions[51].

1.context: title: Pakistan Nutrition SectorCluster: Terms of References ToR - CMAM Technical Working Group  content: BACKGROUNDPakistan is facing triple burden of malnutrition, with very high levels of undernutrition, micronutrient deficiencies as well as increasing trends of overweightobesity, and diet related Non-Communicable Diseases. There is a dire need to review the National CMAM guidelines and update it accordingly with latest national and global recommendations on the subject and as a result ensure the quality and effectiveness of CMAM protocols, strategies, and implementation.

clusters.cluster_headline: Pakistani Authorities Urged to Protect Protesters' Rights and Address Sectarian Violence
clusters.cluster_summary:
The provided sources highlight the urgent need for Pakistani authorities to uphold the right to peaceful protest and assembly, emphasizing the importance of using only the minimum force necessary and ensuring the protection of protesters' rights[1]. Human Rights Watch has reinforced this stance, urging authorities to exercise restraint in their response to demonstrations, release individuals detained for peaceful protest, and restore internet access to facilitate communication[3][4]. These calls align with the United Nations Basic Principles on the Use of Force and Firearms by Law Enforcement Officials, which dictate that security forces must avoid excessive force, using firearms only when less harmful means are impracticable and to the minimum extent necessary, with lethal force reserved solely for situations where it is strictly unavoidable to protect life[7].

Despite these guidelines, there is a notable absence of specific measures addressing the safety and protection of protesters during the monsoon season. Although general updates on the monsoon are mentioned, they do not directly relate to ensuring the safety of protesters in such conditions[7].

In a related context, the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan (HRCP) has expressed deep concern over the significant loss of life in Parachinar, Kurram, where a violent land dispute between rival tribes has exacerbated sectarian conflict[11][12]. This violence has severely affected ordinary citizens, restricting their freedom of movement and access to essential resources such as food and medical supplies[11]. The HRCP has called on the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) government to ensure the maintenance of a brokered ceasefire[11] and has urged the government to facilitate peace negotiations in the area[12]. The commission stressed that all disputes, whether related to land or sectarian issues, should be resolved peacefully through negotiations convened by the KP government, with representation from all stakeholders[11].

7.context: Pakistan's security forces have also carried out enforced disappearances to silence peaceful critics of the government.The nongovernmental organization Human Rights Commission of Pakistan reported that some of the march's organizers received threats to call off the march or face arrest or enforced disappearance. Since July 28, protesters have blocked roads, demanding the release of detained colleagues.The United Nations Basic Principles on the Use of Force and Firearms by Law Enforcement Officials provide that security forces must never use excessive force. In dispersing violent assemblies, firearms may only be used when other less harmful means are not practicable but must still be used to the minimum extent necessary. Law enforcement officers may only intentionally resort to lethal force when strictly unavoidable to protect life.Government authorities generally claim that internet shutdowns are necessary to protect public safety and curb the spread of misinformation.
7.title: Pakistan: Respect Rights in Response to Balochistan March

4.context: title: Pakistan: Respect Rights in Response to Balochistan March  content: New York  Pakistani authorities should exercise restraint in responding to demonstrations in Balochistan province, release all detained for peaceful protest, and restore internet access, Human Rights Watch said today.Since July 28, 2024, Pakistani authorities have detained hundreds of people in response to the Baloch National Gathering, a march seeking to raise awareness of human rights concerns in Balochistan. Some protesters reportedly attacked security forces, killing one soldier and injuring others. Baloch activists have alleged that government security forces have used excessive force to prevent protesters from reaching the port city of Gwadar, the end point of the march. Government authorities have imposed an internet shutdown on Gwadar.
4.title: Pakistan: Respect Rights in Response to Balochistan March

1.context: "Pakistani authorities should uphold the right to peaceful protest and assembly, and when nonviolent means prove ineffective use only the minimum force needed," said Patricia Gossman, associate Asia director at Human Rights Watch. "It's vitally important for the authorities to protect protesters' rights while preventing the situation in Balochistan from spiraling out of control. "The Baloch National Gathering has called for accountability for the numerous cases of enforced disappearances in Balochistan over many years. Such "disappearances" have long been a feature of the conflict between the government and armed militants in Balochistan.
